skills.name: Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10
Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is an integer
Work out the final amount in simple percentage increase problems
Work out the final amount in compound percentage increase problems

explanations.A: It looks like you have given the percentage as the deposit, but we need to calculate 25% of £900. How can we do that?
explanations.B: It looks like you have found 20% of £900. We need to find 25%.
explanations.C: To find 25% of the price, we need to find £900 × 25% which is the same as £900 × 0.25 = £225. You could also find this by calculating 1/2 of £900 = £450 to get 50% and then 1/2 of £450 = £225 to get 25%.
explanations.D: It looks like you have found the remaining amount to pay after the deposit has been paid. We just need to find the deposit amount, 25% of £900.

explanations.A: It looks like you have found the remaining amount to pay after the deposit has been paid. We just need to find the deposit amount, 30% of £800.
explanations.B: It looks like you have found 25% of £800. We need to find 30%.
explanations.C: It looks like you have given the percentage as the deposit, but we need to calculate 30% of £800. How can we do that?
explanations.D: To find 30% of the price we need to find £800 × 30% which is the same as £800 × 0.3 = £240. You could also find this by dividing £800 by 10 to get 10% first and then multiplying by 3. 800 ÷ 10 = 80 and 80 x 3 = £240.

explanations.A: It looks like you have found 20% of the total amount, not the remaining amount after the deposit has been paid. We need to take the deposit of 25% off first and then find 20%.
explanations.B: Nearly! It looks like you have correctly found the remaining amount. Next we need to find the interest that must be paid, which is 20% of this remaining amount.
explanations.C: The remaining amount (after the deposit has been paid) is £900 × 0.75 = £675. The interest is then £675 × 20% = £675 × 0.2 = £135.
explanations.D: It looks like you have found 25% of the remaining amount, but we need to find 20%.

explanations.A: It looks like you've found the total amount that will still be left to pay after the deposit has been paid. Here we just need to know how much the interest will be.
explanations.B: It looks like you have found 25% of the original amount, but we need to subtract the deposit first before we work out the 25% interest.
explanations.C: Nearly! It looks like you have correctly found the remaining amount. Next we need to find the interest that must be paid, which is 25% of this remaining amount.
explanations.D: The remaining amount (after the deposit has been paid) is £800 × 0.7 = £560. The interest is then £560 × 25% = £560 × 0.25 = £140.

explanations.A: Not quite. Remember we have to pay interest with this deal so we need to add this on to the price of the bike.
explanations.B: The remaining amount (after the deposit has been paid) is £900 × 0.75 = £675. The interest is then £675 × 20% = £675 × 0.2 = £135. Adding the interest on to the price of the bike gives a total of £135 + £900 = £1035.
explanations.C: Nearly! You've included the amount after the deposit was paid and you've included the interest. But don't forget to include the deposit, as that counts towards the total amount.
explanations.D: I think you have added the deposit on to the cost of the bike and then worked out the interest as 20% of that. We need to SUBTRACT the deposit from £900 before we calculate the interest.

explanations.A: The remaining amount (after the deposit has been paid) is £800 × 0.7 = £560. The interest is then £560 × 25% = £560 × 0.25 = £140. Adding the interest on to the price of the bike gives a total of £140 + £800 = £940.
explanations.B: It looks like you've found the total amount that will still be left to pay after the deposit has been paid. Here we want to know how much will be paid in total, including the deposit.
explanations.C: Not quite, I think you have found the total cost if we had to pay interest on the WHOLE price of the bike. But we need to subtract the deposit first and work out the interest on the remaining amount. Once we've found the correct amount of interest, we can add that to the price of the bike to get the total cost.
explanations.D: Not quite. Remember we have to pay interest with this deal so we need to add this on to the price of the bike.

explanations.A: I think you have calculated the interest for one year, not two.
explanations.B: Nearly! You have found out the total amount owed but the question asks us to find the interest only.
explanations.C: After 1 year, Kate will owe £6000 x 1.12 = £6720. After two years, Kate will owe £6720 x 1.12 = £7526. This is the same as £6000 × 1.12². Subtracting the original £6000 loan gives the interest as £1526.
explanations.D: I think you have calculated simple interest rather than compound interest. Remember that we need to add the interest from the first year on to the £6000 loan BEFORE we calculate the interest in the second year.

explanations.A: After 1 year, Kate will owe £5000 x 1.14 = £5700. After two years, Kate will owe £5700 x 1.14 = £6498 and after three years, she will owe £6498 x 1.14 = £7407.72. This is the same as 5000 × 1.14^3 = £7407.72. Subtracting the original £5000 loan gives interest as £2,408, to the nearest £1.
explanations.B: I think you have calculated the interest for one year, not three.
explanations.C: Nearly! You have found out the total amount owed but the question asks us to find the interest only.
explanations.D: I think you have calculated simple interest rather than compound interest. Remember that we need to add the interest from the first year on to the £5000 loan BEFORE we calculate the interest in the second year, and so on.

explanations.A: I think you have calculated simple interest rather than compound interest.
explanations.C: Close! I think you have calculated the interest. The question asks us for the total amount that Kate will owe, so we need to include the original loan as well as the interest.
explanations.D: Almost! I think you have calculated the amount owed after 4 years, rather than 5.
